First, wash the eggs thoroughly.
Sometimes when you buy eggs from the
market, they still have chicken
droppings, feathers, dirt, and may even
carry bacteria such as e coli or
salmonella, which can enter the body
through digestion  and cause
stomach pain that is harmful to your
health. Therefore, you should not skip
this step.  Place the eggs in a
large bowl or container.
Add about 1 teaspoon of baking soda
and 1 teaspoon of salt.
Then pour in water until the eggs are
completely submerged.
Stir gently to dissolve the salt and
baking soda. Then soak the eggs for
about 5 minutes. Which country are you

After soaking,
use a clean kitchen towel to gently rub
the surface of each egg to remove any
remaining stains and marks.
Then rinse the eggs again under clean
water and place them on a rack to drain.
When a hen lays an egg, the egg must
pass through the same exit as waste.
When a hen lays an egg,  it
passes through a common passage at the
end of the body, which is also where
waste is expelled. Therefore, the
eggshell  surface often becomes
contaminated with impurities immediately
after being laid. This is why eggshells
are often contaminated  with
feces, feathers, and harmful
microorganisms such as e, coli, and
salmonella. Baking soda loosens dirt
while salt acts as a disinfectant.
As a result, eggs are washed
more thoroughly, eliminating any
unpleasant odors from dirt when boiled,
and we can be more confident about food
safety.  Many people often store
eggs in the refrigerator. But if they
are boiled immediately, the sudden
change in temperature can cause the eggs
to crack  and the whites to stick
to the shell. Sudden temperature changes
can cause eggs to crack and stick to the
shell. Simply soak the eggs in clean
water for about 10 minutes before
boiling. This stabilizes the
temperature, minimizes cracking, and
makes peeling much easier. After
boiling, the eggs crack less and are
much easier to peel.
Eggs are one of the most nutritious
foods. They contain many vitamins,
minerals, protein, and choline, which
are good for the brain and health.
Everyone can eat eggs from young
children to the elderly. Almost anyone
can eat eggs easily. Once the eggs have

about one liter of water to the pot.
Next, add a little salt and stir until
the salt dissolves completely. Salt not
only helps the water boil more steadily,
but also helps the eggs cook evenly and
taste better. Now place a
steamer basket or steaming pot on top of
the pot of water. Then arrange the eggs
in the basket. Usually we boil eggs
directly in water. When the water boils
vigorously,
the eggs are prone to cracking and the
whites or yolks may spill out, reducing
the flavor and being very wasteful.
Additionally, some eggs are very
difficult to peel and look unappealing.
To overcome this, place a small plate in
the center of the steamer. Add a little
vinegar and salt to  the bowl and
stir to dissolve the vinegar and salt to
soften the eggshells, making them easier
to peel. Eggshells are mainly composed
of calcium  carbonate. When
exposed to acetic acid and vinegar, part
of the shell surface is slightly
softened, and the shell will come off
immediately with  just a light
tap. The combination of vinegar and salt
also helps the eggs become softer and
more fragrant after cooking. A small
amount of salt also adds electrolytes
that  are good for your health.
Place the pot on the stove. Turn the
heat to high until the water begins to
boil and steam rises. When steaming, the
eggs do not  touch the water
directly, but are slowly cooked by the
hot steam. Unlike traditional boiling,
this method prevents the eggs from
bumping and cracking during cooking.
Once the water is boiling, reduce the
heat to medium and continue steaming for
about 12 minutes. If you like softboiled
eggs, steam for about 6 minutes. If you
like hard-boiled eggs, steam for about
11 to 12 minutes. Overcooking will make
the eggs dry, hard to digest, and reduce
their flavor. 11 to 12 minutes is the
ideal time. When the time is up, open
the lid, and the eggs will smell
delicious and not fishy. But if you peel

The cold water will help cool the eggs
very quickly and make them easier to
peel. When you place hot eggs in cold
water, the protein inside contracts
slightly, creating a small gap between
the white and the shell. This makes
the shell easier to peel off.

Next, instead of simply eating the
boiled eggs with salt, we will
use them to make a simple egg salad.
Perfect for breakfast or a light meal.
Ingredients include three to four
hard-boiled eggs, one to two tablespoons
of mayonnaise or unsweetened yogurt to
reduce fat, a little dijon mustard,
salt, pepper, finely chopped
onion or spring onion, one finely diced
tomato, a few drops of lemon juice or
apple cider vinegar  along with
toasted bread and lettuce to serve on
the side. Start by peeling the cooled
eggs,  then cut them into
bite-sized pieces. Place them all in a
large bowl.
You will need another bowl to make the
sauce by mixing the mayonnaise with the
Dijon mustard, lemon juice, salt, and
pepper.
Stir well until the sauce is smooth and
blended. If you use unsweetened yogurt,
the flavor will be lighter, which is
perfect for those who like healthy food.
Next, sprinkle  finely chopped
onion or spring onion, tomato, and
cucumber into the bowl of eggs. Pour the
prepared sauce over the eggs and mix
gently to prevent the eggs from
breaking. Mix slowly until all the egg
pieces are coated with the sauce,
ensuring it is evenly distributed. When
the sauce has coated each piece evenly,
the flavor of the salad will be more
harmonious.
You should taste a little and add a
pinch of salt, pepper, or a few drops of
lemon juice if you want to adjust the
flavor to suit your taste.
When enjoying this dish, simply spread a
layer of egg salad onto crispy toasted
bread.  Add a few lettuce leaves
and rock it to enhance the freshness.
The finished dish. Simple, quick,
visually appealing and packed with
energy for a new day.
